meanings.definition: To stuff with seasoning before cooking.
meanings.sent1: The chef farced the turkey with herbs and spices.
meanings.sent2: She always farced the Thanksgiving turkey with a delicious stuffing.
meanings.sent3: The cook farced the chicken with so much seasoning, it danced in the oven!
meanings.sent4: The aroma of the farced roast filled the entire house with warmth and flavor.
meanings.sent5: The chef's secret to a tasty dish was to farce it with a blend of savory herbs.

meanings.definition: To fill with false or irrelevant material.
meanings.sent1: The author farced the essay with unnecessary details to meet the word count.
meanings.sent2: The tabloid farced the article with sensationalized stories to attract readers.
meanings.sent3: The student farced his presentation with random facts to impress the class.
meanings.sent4: Her speech was farced with lies, making it hard to distinguish truth from fiction.
meanings.sent5: The report was farced with inaccuracies, leading to confusion among the readers.

meanings.definition: To force or stuff into a space.
meanings.sent1: He farced his clothes into the suitcase before the trip.
meanings.sent2: The clown farced himself into the tiny car, much to the audience's amusement.
meanings.sent3: The kids farced their toys into the box, struggling to close it.
meanings.sent4: The workers farced the equipment into the small room, barely leaving any space to move.
meanings.sent5: She farced the last piece of the puzzle into place, completing the picture perfectly.
